extraction_metadata.article_title: Stuck Inside a Cloud: Do SaaS business models require a rethink of the traditional approach to public market valuation?

extracted_data.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.extracted_value: SaaS (Software as a Service) - A business model where software is delivered as a service over the internet, typically on a subscription basis, rather than being installed locally on users' computers.
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'This paper explores the rapid growth in the public valuations of SaaS companies' | Page 1: 'Software as a Service companies, which have surged in number and value in recent years' | Page 8: 'subscription business models differ from their traditional counterparts. Subscriptions provide vendors with reliable, steady streams of income over predefined periods'

extracted_data.question_text: Which companies or products are cited as examples of the software business model in the article?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Salesforce → CRM platform example | Blackbaud → Nonprofit software | New Relic → Application performance monitoring | Nutanix → Cloud infrastructure | Talend → Data integration | Yext → Location data management | Healthstream → Healthcare workforce development | RingCentral → Communication platform | Appian → Low-code platform | ServiceNow → IT service management | Paycom → HR and payroll | Veeva → Life sciences cloud | HubSpot → Marketing and sales platform | Benefitfocus → Benefits administration | Atlassian → Development tools | ZenDesk → Customer service | Zix → Email security | MongoDB → Database platform | Blackline → Accounting automation | Coupa → Business spend management

extracted_data.question_text: Are there variations or subtypes of the software business model described in the article?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Best of breed applications → Single software solutions | SaaS suites → Multiple integrated products
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 5: 'One possible distinction which could be made to serve this purpose, is the separation between 'best of breed' applications and SaaS suites. The former, represent companies providing singular pieces of software and are more akin to the growth stocks in Fama and French's conceptual framework. Suites typically contain a multitude of SaaS products or tools'

extracted_data.question_text: What future trends or evolutions are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
